title: Proposal
text: Addressing regional crime disparities in Malaysia requires a deeper understanding of the social and economic factors that contribute to criminal activity. This project aims to investigate if socio-economic factors like unemployment and income inequality drive crime rates and whether they are any crime patterns across different areas. By uncovering these relationships through spatial analysis, we hope to provide insights that support targeted public safety initiatives and effective policy interventions to foster safer, more equitable communities.

This project aims to investigate if socio-economic factors like unemployment and income inequality drive crime rates and whether they are any crime patterns across different areas. title: Proposal
text:
2. Problem Statement
Crime rates in Malaysia vary widely across regions and are often influenced by socioeconomic factors. This project explores whether there is a link between crime and factors such as unemployment rates or income inequality, examining how these may drive criminal activity in different areas. The findings aim to provide insights that can inform public safety and economic policies.

title: Proposal
text:
3. Related Work

3.1 Stimulating Economic Growth, Improving Quality of Life & Enhancing Youth Involvement, Proceedings of International Conference on Contemporary Economic Issues 2014, Kuala Lumpur: Malaysia.
This paper has shed some light on the relationship between poverty, education and income
inequality. While overall poverty incidence is low, pockets of poverty remains particularly
among those living in the rural areas and the Bumiputeras. The incidence of poverty declines
with the level of education attained by the head of households. This negative correlation
between education and poverty is consistent with the prediction and this highlights the
important role played by education, especially at tertiary level and higher in reducing poverty
While level of poverty declines with education, income inequality increases with education.
There is an increase in average income from group to group with more and more members
having higher education but their respective income inequalities are not as clear cut. In other
words, there exist significant differences in income inequality among sub-groups but with no
clear pattern.
Source


3.2 The Impact of Economic Growth, Education Level, and Inflation Rate on Income Inequality in Malaysia
This is an article about income inequality in Malaysia. It discusses the relationship between income inequality and economic growth, education level, and inflation rate. The Gini coefficient is used to measure income inequality. A high Gini coefficient indicates a high level of income inequality. Economic growth in wealthy countries can increase income inequality. However, income inequality in poor countries can impede economic progress.
The conclusion of the article is that economic growth, education level, and inflation rate all have an impact on income inequality in Malaysia. However, the impact of these factors varies depending on the level of economic development. In Malaysia, economic growth has led to an increase in income inequality. However, increasing education levels and reducing inflation rates can help to reduce income inequality.
Source

title: Proposal
text:
4. Data
We will leverage the following datasets from the Malaysian government’s open data platform:

Income Inequality Data: Household income inequality by district (https://data.gov.my/data-catalogue/hh_inequality_district)
School Completion Rates Data: School completion rates by state (https://data.gov.my/data-catalogue/completion_school_state)
Crime Data: Crime rates by district (https://data.gov.my/data-catalogue/crime_district)

Data cleaning and preprocessing will involve handling missing values, merging datasets by geographic regions (district or state), and ensuring consistency in temporal coverage.

title: Proposal
text:
5. Approach
This project will use R Studio as the primary platform for data analysis and visualization.
Our analysis will follow these key steps:

Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (ESDA): Using tools like Moran’s I and Local Indicators of Spatial Association (LISA), we will identify clusters of income inequality and school completion rates to understand if they are randomly distributed or form spatial patterns.
Geographically Weighted Regression (GWR): To explore the relationship between income inequality and school completion rates, we will use GWR to assess how the strength of this relationship varies across regions. We will also include crime rates as a potential confounding variable to see how it interacts with our main variables of interest.

title: Geospatial Analysis of Crimes in Malaysia Against Socio-economic Factors
text:
Resident Abang Smith




AbangSmith is a Shiny application that is designed to explore and analyse the spatial relationships between crime rates and socio-economic factors in Malaysia, such as unemployment rates and income inequality. Leveraging interactive visualisations and geospatial analysis, the application provides users with the tools to uncover regional crime disparities and patterns. By integrating data-driven insights with user-friendly functionality, the platform aims to support researchers, policymakers, and community stakeholders in understanding the drivers of criminal activity.
The application features a range of exploratory data analysis (EDA) tools, such as histograms, boxplots, and spatial maps, allowing users to visualise and analyse crime data alongside relevant socio-economic indicators. Through these capabilities, users can identify trends, patterns, and potential hotspots of criminal activity. The ultimate goal of this tool is to facilitate informed decision-making and empower targeted policy interventions to promote public safety and social equity across Malaysia.
The Shiny application comprises of three pages:

Explanatory Data Analysis (EDA): Allows to generate histogram, box-plot, choropleth maps and LISA map consisting of socio-economic factors.
Geographically Weighted Regression:
Global and Local Spatial Autocorrelation: Allows user to perform Global and Local Moran on the dataset, and plot maps to visualise it. Also allowing users to perform emerging hot spot analysis

      district == "Bandar Bharu" ~ "Bandar Baharu",

      district == "Cameron Highland" ~ "Cameron Highlands",
      district == "Kuala Lipis" ~ "Lipis",
      district %in% c("Batu Gajah", "Ipoh") ~ "Kinta",
      district == "Gerik" ~ "Ulu Perak",

      district == "Kota Kinabatangan" ~ "Kinabatangan",
      district == "Kota Samarahan" ~ "Samarahan",
      district %in% c("Matu Daro", "Tanjung Manis") ~ "Mukah",
      district == "Padawan" ~ "Kuching",
      district == "Kulai" ~ "Kulaijaya",
      district == "Tangkak" ~ "Ledang",
      district == "Kecil Lojing" ~ "Gua Musang",
      district == "Kalabakan" ~ "Tawau",

      district == "Bukit Mabong" ~ "Kapit",

    ))

}

title: Data Wrangling
text:
Combining Crime Type
From the initial prototype of the Shiny application, it was seen that for assault category, there was multiple types of robbery like robbery_gang_armed,robbery_gang_unarmed,robbery_solo_armed and robbery_solo_unarmed. This is the same for the property type with multiple types of vehicle theft like theft_vehicle_lorry,theft_vehicle_motorcar and theft_vehicle_motorcycle. This was causing the large file size as there are multiple rows, so we decided to combine it into a generic type robbery and vehicle_theft.As for the user it would not matter to them on the different types of robbery type or vehicle theft type

msia <- msia %>%
  mutate(cat_type = paste(category, type, sep = "-")) %>%
  select(-category, -type) %>%
  pivot_wider(
    names_from = cat_type,
    values_from = crimes,
    values_fill = 0.0,
    values_fn = mean  # Calculate the mean of duplicate values
  )


msia <- msia %>%
  mutate(
    robbery = `assault-robbery_gang_armed` + `assault-robbery_gang_unarmed` + 
              `assault-robbery_solo_armed` + `assault-robbery_solo_unarmed`,
    vehicle_theft = `property-theft_vehicle_lorry` + `property-theft_vehicle_motorcar` + 
                    `property-theft_vehicle_motorcycle`
  ) %>%
  select(-`assault-robbery_gang_armed`, -`assault-robbery_gang_unarmed`, 
         -`assault-robbery_solo_armed`, -`assault-robbery_solo_unarmed`,
         -`property-theft_vehicle_lorry`, -`property-theft_vehicle_motorcar`, 
         -`property-theft_vehicle_motorcycle`) %>%
  rename_with(~str_remove(., "^assault-|^property-"))

msia <- msia %>%
  select(-"NA-NA")

Remove NA values for the year

msia <- msia[!is.na(msia$year), ]

title: User Guide
text: This serves as guide on how to use our Shiny application

title: User Guide
text:
Navigation Bar

This serves as the main point to navigate the different types of analysis that we did

title: User Guide
text:
EDA

Data Set
This tab allows users to visualise the distribution of the different types of crime, including socio-economic factors. They are presented with a histogram (top-left), box-plot (top-right) and a choropleth map at the bottom.

Users are able to select the variable they would like to explore whether it be socio-economic factors or the different types of crime. They are also able to specify the year they would like to explore. It should be noted that socio-economic factors like gini, income mean, income median, poverty absolute, poverty relative are only available for the years 2019 & 2022. As this is what was given on data.gov.my


LISA
In this tab users are able to explore LISA classification for socio-economic factors as those were not covered in the Spatial Autocorrelation.

Users are able to select the socio-economic factors that they would like for LISA classification and the type of LISA classification. Likewise socio-economic factors like gini, income mean, income median, poverty absolute, poverty relative are only available for the years 2019 & 2022.

title: User Guide
text:
Geographically Weighted Regression

Assumptions Checks

Correlation Analysis
This tab allows users to visualise the correlation between independent variables.

Users are able to select the socio-economic factors (independent variables) that they would want to compare and the type of crime classification. These socio-economic factors are only available for the years 2019 & 2022. Users are also able to select the significant level for the correlation matrix.


Model Performance
This tab assists user to in their decision whether to select stepwise regression models or base model by showing its performance.

Users are able to select the socio-economic factors (independent variables) that they would want to compare and the type of crime classification. These socio-economic factors are only available for the years 2019 & 2022. Users are also able to p value for the stepwise regression models.


Check
This tab assists user to conclude if the assumption checks for geographically weighted regression are met. They are presented with plots/graphs of linearity (top-left), normality check (top-right), outliers (bottom-left), and collinearity (bottom-right).




GWR Model

Map


This tab allows user to compare the local R-squared with that socio-economic factor of their choosing, based on the type of crime and year. Only the years 2019 & 2022 are available as missing data will influence GWR.
Users are able to customise the computation function, approach, distancec metric and stepwise regression model.
After plotting the initial map, user are then able to customise what variables they want to compare with the local R-squared (top map) on the second map (bottom map).


Stats

This tab allows user to view the coefficent estimates and the statistics of the regression model given the parameters selected (identical to the Map tab).

title: User Guide
text:
Spatial Autocorrelation

Global and Local Spatial Autocorrelation

Global Spatial Autocorrelation


This tab allows user to view global and local spatial autocorrelation, we decided to combine it into one tab as a few of the inputs are overlapped between global and local. The results are then displayed on the three tabs on the right.

From here users are able to select the type of crime and year which applies for global and local spatial autocorrelation and LISA.
For choosing which relationship to map to, users are able to choose the socio-economic factor that they would like to show alongside for Local Spatial Autocorrelation and LISA. Likewise socio-economic factors like gini, income mean, income median, poverty absolute, poverty relative are only available for the years 2019 & 2022.
Users are able to customise the weight matrix by selecting the contiguity method (Queen or Rook) and the spatial weights style (row standardized), and the number of simulations to run. This affects Global and Local Autocorrelation and LISA
Users are able to select the type of LISA classification and confidence level which only applies for LISA. And finally users are able to select the local moran stat which applies only for Local Spatial Autocorrelation


Global Spatial Autocorrelation
This is an example of the output for Global Spatial Autocorrelation, it shows the Global Moran Test on the top left, and the Monte-Carlo Simulation on the top right which is to double confirm the results of the Global Moran Test. And the histogram on the bottom shows the distribution of the results from the Monte-Carlo Simulation.
Having a positive Moran I statistic suggest that there is clustering, while a negative Moran I statistic suggest spatial dispersion. Also a small p-value of < 0.05 suggest that it might not have happened randomly, while a p-value > 0.05 suggest that it might have occured randomly.



Local Spatial Autocorrelation
This is an example of the output for Local Spatial Autocorrelation, where it shows the Local Moran Stat that was chosen indicated by the top right indicator, where it is map along side the type of socio-economic factor that was chosen, indicated by the numbers on the map. From here user can make an inference of whether the Local Moran Stat chosen was statistically significant and whether it correlates to the socio-economic factor that was chosen.



LISA
An example of the output for LISA where it shows the LISA map based on the type of LISA class that was chosen which is mapped to the socio-economic factor that was chosen.

High-Low Outliers: Districts with a high value of the type of crime, surrounded by neighbouring districts with low values of the type of crime.
Low-High Outliers: Districts with a low value of the type of crime, surrounded by neighbouring districts with high values of the type of crime.
High-High Clusters: Districts with a high value of the type of crime, surrounded by neighbouring Districts with high values of the type of crime.
Low-Low Clusters: Districts with a low value of the type of crime, surrounded by neighbouring Districts with low values of the type of crime.

Users are to see if there are any significance with the LISA classification with the type of socio-economic factor.




Emerging Hot Spot Analysis
This tab allows users to run emerging_hotspot_analysis() on the type of crime. Users are able to select the type of crime to perform emerging hot spot analysis on, number of simulations to let it run and choosing the significance level which would affect the outputs on the right.
Users are able to see the hot spot classification on the map after running the analysis and the distribution of the classification on the bar graph below.
For the classification:
Credits to https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/tool-reference/space-time-pattern-mining/learnmoreemerging.htm#GUID-09587AFC-F5EC-4AEB-BE8F-0E0A26AB9230







Classification
Definition




No Pattern Detected
Does not fall into any of the hot or cold spot patterns defined below.


New Hot Spot
A location that is a statistically significant hot spot for the final time step and has never been a statistically significant hot spot before.


Consecutive Hot Spot
A location with a single uninterrupted run of at least two statistically significant hot spot bins in the final time-step intervals. The location has never been a statistically significant hot spot prior to the final hot spot run and less than 90 percent of all bins are statistically significant hot spots.


Intensifying Hot Spot
A location that has been a statistically significant hot spot for 90 percent of the time-step intervals, including the final time step. In addition, the intensity of clustering of high counts in each time step is increasing overall and that increase is statistically significant.


Persistent Hot Spot
A location that has been a statistically significant hot spot for 90 percent of the time-step intervals with no discernible trend in the intensity of clustering over time.


Diminishing Hot Spot
A location that has been a statistically significant hot spot for 90 percent of the time-step intervals, including the final time step. In addition, the intensity of clustering in each time step is decreasing overall and that decrease is statistically significant.


Sporadic Hot Spot
A statistically significant hot spot for the final time-step interval with a history of also being an on-again and off-again hot spot. Less than 90 percent of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant hot spots and none of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant cold spots.


Oscillating Hot Spot
A statistically significant hot spot for the final time-step interval that has a history of also being a statistically significant cold spot during a prior time step. Less than 90 percent of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant hot spots.


Historical Hot Spot
The most recent time period is not hot, but at least 90 percent of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant hot spots.


New Cold Spot
A location that is a statistically significant cold spot for the final time step and has never been a statistically significant cold spot before.


Consecutive Cold Spot
A location with a single uninterrupted run of at least two statistically significant cold spot bins in the final time-step intervals. The location has never been a statistically significant cold spot prior to the final cold spot run and less than 90 percent of all bins are statistically significant cold spots.


Intensifying Cold Spot
A location that has been a statistically significant cold spot for 90 percent of the time-step intervals, including the final time step. In addition, the intensity of clustering of low counts in each time step is increasing overall and that increase is statistically significant.


Persistent Cold Spot
A location that has been a statistically significant cold spot for 90 percent of the time-step intervals with no discernible trend in the intensity of clustering of counts over time.


Diminishing Cold Spot
A location that has been a statistically significant cold spot for 90 percent of the time-step intervals, including the final time step. In addition, the intensity of clustering of low counts in each time step is decreasing overall and that decrease is statistically significant.


Sporadic Cold Spot
A statistically significant cold spot for the final time-step interval with a history of also being an on-again and off-again cold spot. Less than 90 percent of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant cold spots and none of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant hot spots.


Oscillating Cold Spot
A statistically significant cold spot for the final time-step interval that has a history of also being a statistically significant hot spot during a prior time step. Less than 90 percent of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant cold spots.


Historical Cold Spot
The most recent time period is not cold, but at least 90 percent of the time-step intervals have been statistically significant cold spots.
